homeFounder.title: Female Founders
homeFounder.subtitle: Lupita, 38 years
homeFounder.descriptionOne: Female Founders is our internal program for testing and get feedback on EVA. Thanks to the participation of voluntary women, we can continue to improve the development of EVA and compile data to train our artificial intelligence algorithms.
homeFounder.descriptionTwo: Learn about the history of Lupita, a cancer survivor and volunteer for our campaign.

homeAllies.title: Our allies
homeAllies.description: In our fight to revolutionize early breast cancer detection, we count on key allies that push us and support Higia Technologies in various areas of its daily operation.

donors.title: First Donors
donors.desc: Our purpose began to come alive the day that the first people believed in our dream of revolutionizing breast cancer detection.
donors.descBold: Thank you to all our donors of our Inixar campaign.

cover.title: Allies
cover.descPt1: In our fight to revolutionize early breast cancer detection, we count on key allies that boost us and support
cover.descPt2: in different areas of its daily operation.

cards.title: Research, test campaigns, marketing strategies
cards.desc: In collaboration with AXA we have realized test campaigns such as Mujeres Fundadoras (Female Founders) and we are working on developing marketing strategies that allow EVA to reach a greater number of women.

cards.title: Clinical tests
cards.desc: Thanks to IMSS, we will perform clinical trials in Mexico with more than 600 women.

cards.title: Clinical tests
cards.desc: Together with Stanford Medicine we will start clinical trials to get the approval of the FDA.

cards.title: Investor
cards.desc: Higia is a company funded by Y Combinator, the most prestigious company accelerator on a global level.

cards.title: Marketing strategies in Asia
cards.desc: In collaboration with Kowa we are starting to explore ways for EVA to reach more women around the world.

cards.title: Data hosting, IT Services
cards.desc: Thanks to KIO Networks, the clinical data of our patients are protected in the cloud.

cards.title: Software development
cards.desc: Thanks to the support of BEEVA, we continue to improve the software behind EVA every day.

cards.title: Manufacture and production processes
cards.desc: In collaboration with Molex we work to perfect the electronics and the manufacturing processes behind EVA.

cards.title: Research
cards.desc: Together, Higia and Tómatelo a Pecho are fighting breast cancer, accelerating the development of EVA through mentors of the medical field.

cards.title: Test campaigns
cards.desc: Together, Higia and Tepoz Rosa fight to deliver screening and early diagnostic tools to rural communities.

cards.title: Research, development of business model
cards.desc: With the support of the MD Anderson I-Corps Regional Program launched by the National Science Foundation we have been able to validate our business model responding to the needs of our users, strengthening our proposal of worth based on the needs of our users.

cards.title: Data hosting, IT services
cards.desc: Thanks to Google, we are working hand in hand with first-level researchers on the development of the algorithms to detect diseases.

whoarewe.title: Our
whoarewe.desc: We are empowering people to take control of their well-being through the development of innovative technology that allows the access to actionable information about their health.

timeline.desc: Graciela Ríos (mother of Julián Ríos) is diagnosed with breast cancer.
The first idea of EVA is born "Professionalization of the self-exploration method of the breast".
Higia wins the Babson University Innovation Challenge with the concept of EVA.
Julian joins forces with Antonio Torres and José Lavariega. The formal development of EVA begins.
The first "minimum viable product" of EVA is born.
timeline.descTwo: Higia hires its first collaborator: Fernando López (Director of software).

timeline.desc: Higia wins the National Student Entrepreneur Award.
timeline.descTwo: InvestoVC and its union of angel investors make the first external investment in Higia.

timeline.desc: Raymundo González (Director of Artificial Intelligence) and Martín Urtiz (Leading algorithm developer) join.
Higia gets first place at the Everis Awards (1 million MXN).
The investment fund ID345 invests in the pre-seed round of investment of Higia.
timeline.descTwo: Higia becomes the first Mexican company to be awarded the Global Student Entrepreneur Award.

timeline.desc: The Mexican President Enrique Peña Nieto awards Higia Tech with the Presidential Medal in Technology and Entrepreneurship.

EVA is presented at the Congress of Future Medical Leaders of the United States in front of 8,000 people. Higia’s team is invited to give a conference at the Harvard University and MIT Innovation Laboratories.
Higia collaborates with AXA Insurance to test EVA with 500 women.
timeline.descTwo: Higia performs the launching event of EVA in Mexico City.

timeline.desc: Higia adds 8 new employees to the family and moves operations to Mexico City.
Higia is recognized as one of the most promising companies of 2018 by Forbes Magazine.
The Female Founders program is executed for the first time with 60 patients with the new version of EVA.
Higia Tech moves to Silicon Valley for YCombinator accelerator.

team.title: #Team
team.desc: We are a group of Mexicans working in Artificial Intelligence, Software and Hardware from Mexico City, Puebla and Monterrey.

card.modalDesc1: After watching his mother’s painful battle against breast cancer, Julián Ríos Cantú made his personal mission to make an impact through early detection of breast cancer. Currently, he is the CEO and co-founder of Higia Technologies.
card.modalDesc2: Julián has been awarded the National Medal for Technology and Innovation of Mexico and the Vanguard Award from Minerva University for his research about breast cancer detection technology. He has been a guest professor at the National Congress of Medicine of the United States and at the Harvard University and MIT Innovation Laboratories. In May 2017, Julián became the first Mexican to win the Global Student Entrepreneur Award. Recently, Higia has been appointed one of the 30 most promising companies of Mexico for 2018 by Forbes and EVA as one of the principal medical innovations by the National Congress of Medicine of the United States.

card.modalDesc1: Raymundo runs the field of Artificial Intelligence, leader of research and development of model technology and algorithm of Machine Learning to perform the best data analysis, assuring that EVA provides useful information for its users. Ray contributes to his field and to the whole company a vision of possible uses of our technology, from understanding our product’s perception from various cultural perspectives on to experience in multicultural teams with members working remotely. Ray relies on experience working with the Stanford University Artificial Intelligence Laboratory and as a research intern at Audible, an Amazon company.
card.modalDesc2: "With Higia I saw an opportunity to continue learning and improving my abilities in the field that interest me the most, to continue developing professionally and be part of a project that can have an impact on a great number of people, including saving lives. All this in a team of highly motivated and competent people".

card.modalDesc1: Motivated by his grandmother’s fight against breast cancer as well as the technical challenge that represented the creation of EVA, Antonio joined Julián in the research and development that lead to the development of Higia Technologies.
card.modalDesc2: As Chief Technology Officer, Antonio main role is to assure Higia Technologies relies on the correct tools to achieve the purpose of providing people with actionable insights about their health through technological innovations. Moreover, he leads the creation of the technology and the taking of risks to improve the development of the products within the different teams that form Higia. Antonio has been responsible for carrying the joint vision of the software and hardware development by means of experimentation, prototyping and analyzing the ideas that can accelerate the processes and improve the products of the company.

card.modalDesc1: Fernando is in charge of designing and coordinating the development of the software platforms of Higia Tech, incorporating the best technologies that allow the rest of the team an agile and scalable development. Thanks to his training as an Engineer of Computational Technology and his continuous restlessness to question ideas, Fernando leads his area to develop software focused on improving people’s quality of life.
card.modalDesc2: "I have always been interested in applying the knowledge of software development to products that improve people’s quality of life. The opportunity to work at Higia was extraordinary because it combines a positive impact with a focus on health through prevention using different technologies of different study fields".

card.modalDesc1: Electronic engineer, hardware design, firmware, and robotics. With 6 years of experience leading the hardware development of medical devices, Victor is in charge of developing the necessary technology so that EVA is able to detect abnormalities in the breasts and report those. Through research and experience in electronic development and programming, we can reduce the feeling of vulnerability and uncertainty of women that are facing the monitoring of their breast health As Chief Hardware Engineer, Victor is working with members of other areas to support, suggest and improve the ideas together, searching for the synergy of ideas to receive the best results.
card.modalDesc2: "Higia is a company with enormous potential, but above all, it is a company with a humanist and social vision. Here we can get professional and personal growth, and it’s a company that matches my values. I contribute my experience and vision to help position Higia as the global benchmark for technology devices that improve women’s quality of life".

card.modalDesc1: Carlos leads the Product Development team and with more than six years of experience in logistics and product development, from the concept’s creation to its manufacturing and distribution, he works closely with the Hardware team, anticipating the complexity and the challenges that represent the development of a product like EVA. Thanks to the versatility of the products that Carlos has developed, he provides a strategic vision to ask the right questions before making decisions, creating guidelines, understanding those and assuring that they are followed to be able to reach the final development of the product.

Industrial Designer with a great interest in designing products, services and systems that positively affect the society. Ale works with Higia Technologies to continue developing a strong team, a solid organizational culture and tools for communication for EVA and Higia to be able to go further.
card.modalDesc2: "It fills me with excitement to form part of a company of young Mexican entrepreneurs, to which I can contribute a creative and analytical vision to work on solutions that allow us to improve women’s quality of life and, in the future, have a positive impact on the health of a great number of people".

card.modalDesc1: Engineer of Computational Technologies, specializing in backend developing and the integration of Amazon Web Services. Juan José focuses his strengths on laying the foundations of the technological infrastructure on which the solutions that allow us to achieve our goals, are built; therefore, as a team, we can succeed facing the challenges that present themselves and rebuild in order to adapt to the future.
card.modalDesc2: "The opportunity to contribute my skills and experiences to creating a solution that improves the well-being of women around the world brought me to Higia".

card.modalDesc1: José Antonio leads the development of the mobile applications of EVA for the platform Android, as well as the design of the user experience. Thanks to his passion for technology and his great creativity, Tony provides the Software team with different ideas and solutions for existing problems to receive new and better results. José Antonio has experience working with companies like Google in Mountain View, California.
card.modalDesc2: "I consider Higia’s future in the industry impressive and the simple fact of being able to be part of the history we’re writing is a feeling that fills me with happiness and inspiration. The team is growing so that every contribution has a big impact. Everything is a challenge which makes it more interesting".

card.modalDesc1: An expert in observing every step of the process that forms the usability of the products to be able to make the best decision for the design of the experience. María is responsible for leading the analysis and selection of the design’s characteristics to assure that EVA is a functional and comfortable product, with which people can have a truly efficient and successful interaction with. María evaluates and proposes solutions for the challenges that present itself in the design of the user experience of EVA, as much on an ergonomic as well as on a psychological level.

Industrial designer specialized in the design for manufacturing, as well as the examination and the application of materials in various fields of the production. Osmar promotes the constant experimentation within the development and the hardware team, suggesting materials, forms and processes to apply to the device that will assure to obtain a robust design and with the necessary characteristics for a production on a large scale.

Student at Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) Class of 2022 in Business Analytics (Sloan School of Management) and Aeronautical Engineering. As Research Leader, José is in charge of visualizing the long-term development of the company by means of searching for new technologies and their implementation in the development of Higia’s products. José executes the extensive research together with international researchers to identify areas of opportunity and growth for the future of the company.
card.modalDesc2: "It motivates me to work as part of Higia’s team to make accessible and improve the Mexican and global infrastructure of breast cancer".

card.modalDesc1: Gaby is in charge of developing the image and corporate identity of Higia Technologies, always searching to generate content that transmits our vision and brings us closer to the people seeking to take control of their health by means of monitoring and prevention. With her great creativity and energy, Gaby creates the necessary tools to be able to tell the world of the history of EVA.
card.modalDesc2: "Being part of the team of Higia Technologies fills me with enthusiasm and motivation since I can contribute in a small way to this great company that surely will positively impact the world and the health of thousands of people. Being part of Higia is being part of a big challenge. We are motivated to be the best because lots of people will benefit from it".

card.modalDesc1: Digital Data Engineer, Martín is in charge of guiding the development of Higia by means of novel technologies to reach excellence in the diagnosis of breast cancer. Thanks to his creativity and broad knowledge of Machine Learning, Martín motivates the team to find and implement solutions that are out of the ordinary, which help to improve our predictive algorithms. Martín has experience working with companies like Google in Mountain View, California.
card.modalDesc2: "It moves me to think that my work at Higia will have the impact of saving lives of a large number of people, thanks to a timely cancer diagnosis".

card.modalDesc1: Expert in developing businesses and passionate about the use of exponential technologies to have a positive impact on the world. Alumni of Tecnológico de Monterrey, UC Berkeley, Draper University and Singularity University, Angie currently works with Higia Technologies as an advisor on topics related to investment strategy.
card.modalDesc2: "A team filled with passion for solving a very important problem. I particularly like the vision for the future and their drive to make this work".

card.title: Frontend Software Engineer
card.desc: Estamos buscando un ingeniero que tenga la capacidad de analizar, diseñar, implementar, poner en producción y monitorear interfaces de usuario web, usando tecnologías frontend modernas.

card.title: Frontend Software Engineer
card.desc: Estamos buscando un ingeniero que tenga la capacidad de analizar, diseñar, implementar, poner en producción y monitorear interfaces de usuario web, usando tecnologías frontend modernas.

cover.descPart3: wearable designed to detect abnormalities in the thermal patterns of the breast, an indicator for the

info.desc1: EVA is equipped with sensors that collect thermal data of the surface of the breasts, with which the thermal patterns on the breast are mapped.
info.desc2: This allows a professionalization of the auto-examination, complementing the conventional methods of diagnosis and screening.

proofs.title: Where are we at?
proofs.percentages: Currently, the sensibility of EVA is at 87.9% and its specificity is at 81.7%
proofs.desc1: These results have been estimated through a process of cross-validation of 153 women, with 33 of them having breast cancer confirmed through a mammogram or biopsy.
proofs.desc2: At Higia Technologies we are preparing to continue realizing clinical trials in Mexico and abroad, together with allies such as Stanford Medicine, the Mexican Institute for Social Security and AXA Insurances.

get.desc: available in the App Store and Google Play.

work.desc: and follow the instructions to start the examination.

analyze the information to the information to create an evaluation* in a matter of minutes.

work.desc: provides you with a plan of action to put you in contact with a doctor in order to perform the necessary clinical analysis.

steps.note: *EVA sends out an evaluation, not a diagnosis, this can only be expressed by a doctor after having performed an appropriate clinical analysis.
steps.toolPart2: does not replace a mammography, it is a complementary tool that professionalizes the auto-examination of the breasts made available for women from the age of 25 years on. It is a safe and reliable method to monitor the health of your breasts.

question.title: 1. What’s the cost of EVA?
question.answer: At the moment we don't have a defined sales price, however, we are working day after day to make it as accessible as possible so that EVA can positively impact the lives of a large number of women, regardless of their socioeconomic status.

question.title: 2. Where can I buy EVA?
question.answer: Currently, EVA is not yet available for purchase. However, you can register
question.answerContinuation: to be part of our pre-sale campaign. Once you are registered, you will enter a waitlist to purchase the device when it’s available for sale and you will receive updates related to the company through email.

question.title: 3. What is the pre-order?
question.answer: It’s a register through which you will form part of a waitlist to be one of the first people to buy EVA when it is ready for sale.

question.title: 4. When will be EVA be on sale in Mexico?
question.answer: As soon as we finish performing the tests and the corresponding certifications we will be in touch with the registered people from our waitlist. We expect EVA to be available by the end of 2019.

question.title: 5. When is EVA on sale outside of Mexico?
question.answer: We don’t have any date yet, but we are working on this.

question.title: 6. How does EVA work?
question.answer: EVA is a device designed to detect abnormalities in the thermal patterns of the breast. The patches collect data that are sent to the phone or tablet of the user through Bluetooth technology. Our Artificial Intelligence algorithms, then, generate a risk evaluation in a matter of minutes.
question.answerPart2: A great number of tumors surround themselves with blood vessels in order to grow. In the same way, the tumors emit a greater heat for having an elevated rate of cellular reproduction. This causes a hot zone around the tumor that EVA analyzes to generate a risk evaluation through Artificial Intelligence algorithms.

question.title: 7. From which age on can I use EVA?
question.answer: You can start using EVA from the age of 25 years on.

question.title: 8. What will be the lifetime of EVA?
question.answer: For now, we don’t have an exact lifetime. This will, to a great extent, depend on the cycle of use of the product, that is to say, the frequency with which EVA will be used and the care it will be given by its user. We are focused on making EVA a product that stays in the life of its user for the longest time possible.

question.title: 9. Is the examination painful? / Does it present any risk to my health?
question.answer: The examination with EVA is painless, non-invasive and doesn’t present any risk to your health.

question.title: 10. Can I wash my EVA - The Auto-exploration Wearable?
question.answer: With the current version, this is not possible. However, we are working on making EVA washable.

question.title: 11. Is it possible to use the same device on more than one person?
question.answer: We are working on a multi-user platform for EVA. Even though the additional users would not have to pay for the device, they would have to pay for a monthly membership for the use of the mobile application, data storage and personalized medical attention.

question.title: 12. Does EVA emit any type of radiation?
question.answer: EVA is a non-invasive device that doesn’t present any risk to the user’s health.

question.title: 13. What is the procedure if EVA The Auto-exploration Wearable indicates the possible presence of breast cancer?
question.answer: EVA immediately connects you with health professionals through one of our platforms. As soon as our algorithms detect abnormalities, the doctors will propose a plan of action to give you immediate medical attention and mitigate the possible risk.

kitPress.title: Press Kit
kitPress.desc: We’d like to thank you for your interest in sharing our story! To download our Press Kit, we invite you to fill out the following form.

density.title: High breast density
density.desc: 40% of the female population in the USA and 80% of the female population in Asian countries have high breast density, which means that they have from 2 to 6 times more likelihood of developing breast cancer throughout their lifetime. Furthermore, dense tissue "masks" tumors in the breast by making it harder for physicians to differentiate between healthy tissue and abnormal masses. Likewise, a study conducted with more than 70,000 patients in the Netherlands showed that the sensitivity of the mammogram was reduced by 29% in women with high breast density. Also, studies have shown that tumors in dense breast tissue might progress more rapidly than those in fatty breasts. In conclusion, there are 23.1 million women in the US alone that 1) have a higher risk of developing breast cancer and 2) tumors would grow more aggressively in their breasts and are the ones least likely to benefit from a mammogram.
density.subtitle: How we aim to solve this
density.descTwo: The detection of breast cancer through the analysis of thermal patterns inside the breast has proven to be agnostic to tissue density. This means that a device like EVA can detect tumors with the same sensitivity and specificity in women with high breast density as in those with fatty breast tissue. EVA can become an important adjunctive tool for breast cancer screening in populations with high breast density. Studies have shown that thermographic screening methods combined with mammogram tests can lead to a joint sensitivity of 95%.

neglected.title: Neglected populations
neglected.descOne: According to the American Cancer Society, women aged 40 to 44 should have the choice to start screening annually for breast cancer with mammograms if they wish to do so and women aged 45 to 54 should get mammograms every year. It's important to clarify that the mammogram has not been shown to be clinically beneficial or cost-effective in the evaluation of breast symptoms in women under the age of 35. This means that just in the US, 51.6 million women aged 25 to 40 do not have access to the only method that has been clinically proven to reduce breast cancer mortality rates, in other words, they are excluded from the breast cancer screening guidelines.
neglected.descTwo: Early breast cancer detection in young women remains one of the main challenges for effectively fighting this disease. The World Health Organization predicts that the incidence of breast cancer in young women will increase by 50% by 2035, and reports that, currently, 7% of breast cancer cases are women younger than 40 years of age. Young women are more likely to have high breast density, be diagnosed at more advanced stages, have a survival rate of less than 5 years, and have no access to a reliable method of breast cancer screening.
neglected.subtitle: How we aim to solve this
neglected.descThree: The mammogram is not available for young women due to concerns relating to prolonged exposure to radiation and its low sensitivity with the high breast density common in this age group. Contrary to the mammogram, EVA does not emit any type of ionizing radiation nor compress the mammary gland in any form, as well as being non-invasive and completely pain-free. This allows us to be an age-agnostic adjunctive screening technique that can be used by any woman since age 20.

infrastructure.title: Infrastructure costs
infrastructure.descOne: Breast cancer is a disease that affects both the rich and the poor. Nonetheless, suffering due to breast cancer mainly impacts the poor. Low socioeconomic status is a consistent marker of mammogram underuse: 70% of breast cancer cases in developing countries like Mexico are in stage III and IV, which are stages that reduce the survival rate to just 25%. This can be explained by the fact that breast cancer in young women is more common in developing countries (accounting for 35% of all cases) and since there is no reliable method for breast cancer screening, only 5-10% of the diagnostics occur in the early stages.
infrastructure.descTwo: Women above 40 years of age in developing countries rarely have access to quality mammograms due to high infrastructure costs and lack of access to cost-effective transportation to hospitals and clinics with the adequate equipment.
infrastructure.subtitle: How we aim to solve this

solutions.title: Costs:
solutions.desc: The infrastructure costs of EVA are close to zero when compared to the costs of common screening techniques.

solutions.title: A tool for young populations:
solutions.desc: Developing countries have the difficult task of fighting breast cancer in young women, and until now there was no screening method for this particular population. EVA has the opportunity to become the gold standard screening technique for women between the age of 25 and 40.

solutions.title: Cultural barriers:
solutions.desc: One of the reasons why low socioeconomic status is a consistent marker for mammography underuse is the fact that this population has an erroneous bad impression of the risks associated with the mammogram and the physical exposure it requires. Since EVA is a radiation-free device for personal use and does not require physical exposure, it might have a higher acceptance rate within rural and marginalized communities.

cases.title: Cases for additional use
cases.desc: In some cases, treatment with chemotherapy, targeted therapy, or hormone therapy may be given before breast surgery. This is called neoadjuvant therapy and has the purpose of shrinking a cancer tumor before surgical intervention. EVA can be used as an accessible and personal tool for tracking the effectiveness of neoadjuvant therapy by assessing if a tumor is indeed being reduced in size week-by-week through the analysis of its thermal footprint.

list.title: Effect of mammographic breast density on breast cancer screening performance: a study in Nijmegen, The Netherlands
American Cancer Society Guidelines for the Early Detection of Cancer
Personalizing Mammography by Breast Density and Other Risk Factors for Breast Cancer: Analysis of Health Benefits and Cost-Effectiveness
